subject: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
msgSnippet: Nope. Just set up two project root directories (an additional sourcepath entry) e.g. src & test. Say I have a file toplevel.nextlevel.MyClass, the production
messageBody:
Nope. Just set up two project root directories (an additional sourcepath
entry) e.g. src & test.
Say I have a file toplevel.nextlevel.MyClass, the production source would be
in src/toplevel/nextlevel/MyClass.java and the test source would be in
test/toplevel/nextlevel/TestMyClass.java

Covered in the faq for Junit.

Hope this helps.

-----Original Message-----
From: Ray Tayek [mailto:rtayek@...]
Sent: 22 February 2002 11:31
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: JavaDocs

At 09:53 AM 2/21/02 -0800, you wrote:
>First, let's get to the initial topic of this thread.
>
>As posted previousely by several other fellow developers, you can always
>have two source paths, one for the source and one for the test cases.
> In this way, JavaDoc will not have any problems any more. ...

pm4ji, but are you implying that the source for test classes will be in a
different directory? (this would mean that the test class can not belong to
the same package as class that it is testing).

thanks
